analytic.title: Medical Image Analysis

biblStruct.note: Received 13 August 2020 Revised 7 June 2021 Accepted 2 July 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Dynamic functional connectivity Single-sided deafness Different tem poral term Nodal efficiency-based correlation matrix rs-fMRI SSD, single-sided deafness
rs-fMRI, resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging
rdFC, randomized window-based dynamic functional connectivity

div.p: As an extreme type of partial auditory deprivation, single-sided deafness (SSD) has been demonstrated to lead to extensive neural plasticity according to multimodal neuroimaging studies. Among them, restingstate functional magnetic resonance imaging (rs-fMRI) offers valuable information on functional connectivities (FCs). However, most previous SSD rs-fMRI studies assumed that the extracted FC remains stationary during the entire fMRI scan and neglected dynamic functional activities. Existing fixed windowbased dynamic FC analysis also ignores dynamic functional activities under different tem poral terms. Additionally, due to the cost constraints of using MRI machines, using data-driven methods for unbiased hypothesis investigations may require more effective sample data augmentation techniques. To tackle these challenges and problems together, in this study, we proposed a dynamic window with a random length and position to extract participants' dynamic characteristics under different temporal terms and to extract more information from the dataset. Then, we proposed a nodal efficiency-based correlation matrix to describe the relationships of synergism between regions as features and applied a linear support vector machine (SVM) model to learn the importance of the features, which helped to identify SSD patients and healthy controls. A total of 68 participants (including 23 with left SSD, 20 with right SSD and 25 healthy controls) were enrolled. Our proposed approach with a random window showed clear improvement compared with traditional static and fixed window-based dynamic FC by using the linear SVM model. FCs related to the frontoparietal, somatomotor, dorsal attention, limbic and default mode networks played significant roles in differentiating SSD patients from healthy controls. Additionally, FCs between the somatomotor and frontoparietal networks made the greatest contribution to the classification model. Regarding brain regions, FCs related to the superior frontal gyrus, superior parietal lobule, superior temporal gyrus, amygdala, and orbital gyrus played significant roles. These findings suggest that networks and regions related to higher-order cognitive functions showed the most significant FC alterations in SSD, which may represent a compensatory collaboration of cognitive resources in SSD.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Hearing loss is the most prevalent sensory disability. In addition to bilateral severe-to-profound deafness, i.e., patients with total hearing deprivation, a larger proportion of patients have partial hearing deprivation. Single-sided deafness (SSD) is an extreme condition of partial hearing deprivation. The etiology of SSD can be both congenital and acquired, and the latter includes idiopathic sudden sensorineural hearing loss, acoustic neuroma, Meniere's disease and trauma. Although an accurate prevalence is not available for SSD, the incidence of unilateral hearing loss ranges from 3 to 9.3% in different populations ( Jun et al., 2015 ;Ross et al., 2010 ;Shargorodsky et al., 2010 ), and a large proportion of these patients are SSD cases.

The main auditory influences of SSD are reduced abilities of sound localization and speech recognition in noise because of the absence of intensity differences, binaural squelch, and interaural time differences ( Abel and Lam, 2008 ;Bess and Tharpe, 1986 ;Ruscetta et al., 2005 ). Since daily communication ability is mostly maintained, hearing rehabilitation measures are used in only a small portion of SSD patients in the clinic, although hearing aids and cochlear implants are able to rehabilitate the hearing ability of deaf ears to a great extent. However, growing evidence has suggested that SSD affects individuals far more extensively than in terms of hearing, including through emotional problems, psychosocial handicaps and even educational problems, according to behavioral studies ( Bovo et al., 1988 ;Lieu, 2004 ;Lieu et al., 2012 ). Thus, further clarification of the influence of SSD is crucial for informing intervention strategies.

The brain is a dynamic self-organizing system, and the development of the connectome is highly dependent on sensory experience ( Kral, 2013 ;Kral et al., 2016 ). In subjects with complete sensory deprivation, such as bilateral deafness, hearing loss has been demonstrated to lead to stronger coupling with other sensory systems, reorganization within the auditory system or a different use of structures in recruiting attention and its interactions with auditory and nonauditory areas ( Kral et al., 2016 ). Furthermore, top-down interactions are markedly affected as well. The effects of hearing deprivation may range from the gene expression level ( Pernia et al., 2020 ) and cellular level ( Barone et al., 2013 ) to the social level ( Castellanos et al., 2015 ;Figueras et al., 2008 ). As a partial auditory deprivation condition, brain reorganization in SSD is more complicated but less investigated.

Multimodal neuroimaging studies in SSD provide deep insight and have revealed brain structural and functional alterations among not only auditory-related regions but also nonauditoryrelated regions ( Dewey and Hartley, 2015 ;Han et al., 2018 ;Kim et al., 2018 ;Lee et al., 2017 ;Li et al., 2019 ;Lomber et al., 2010 ;Qiao et al., 2019 ;Rosemann and Thiel, 2018 ;Schmithorst et al., 2014 ;Shang et al., 2020 ;Shang et al., 2018 ;Wang et al., 2014 ;Wang et al., 2016 ). Structural MRI studies using voxel-based morphometry revealed altered gray matter volume not only in the auditory cortex but also in regions in the somatosensory, motor and visual systems ( Wang et al., 2016 ). In addition to structural alterations of the auditory pathway, including the lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus, diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) studies have also revealed extensive fractional anisotropy reduction in nonauditory tracts and regions, including the frontoparietal and occipital lobes ( Lin et al., 2008 ;Rachakonda et al., 2014 ;Shang et al., 2018 ;Wu et al., 2009 ). Li et al. 2019 structural network study using tractography of DTI revealed enhanced connectivity in the frontoparietal network and decreased connectivity in the visual network ( Li et al., 2019 ). Regarding function, both auditory evoked potentials and magnetic fields showed more symmetrical and synchronous central auditory system activation when auditory stimuli were given only to the healthy ear in SSD ( Khosla et al., 2003 ;Ponton et al., 2001 ;Pross et al., 2015 ), suggesting reorganization in favor of the healthy ear, which is consistent with findings in animal models ( Kral et al., 2013a ;Kral et al., 2013b ;Tillein et al., 2016 ). Furthermore, an auditory working memory task study using magnetoencephalography (MEG) revealed decreased induced gamma band oscillations over the frontal and parietal cortices between 175 and 475 ms following stimulus onset ( Shang et al., 2018 ).

By quantifying fluctuations in cerebral blood oxygen level dependence (BOLD), functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is a reliable method of investigating brain activity with high spatial resolution. Consistent with the auditory evoked potential (AEP) and MEG findings, fMRI studies using auditory stimuli showed more symmetrical activation of the auditory cortices ( Langers et al., 2005 ). fMRI studies using audio-visual or visual tasks revealed activation alterations in both auditory and visual cortices ( Qiao et al., 2019 ;Schmithorst et al., 2014 ), suggesting cross-modal plasticity in SSD. fMRI studies involving auditory tasks revealed activation alterations in both auditory-associated cerebral regions and areas of the attention network ( Propst et al., 2010 ). Using a visual working memory task, Qiao et al. (2019) observed decreased activation in the frontoparietal regions in SSD, which was conjectured to be the result of additional recruitment of cognitive resources for hearing as a compensatory mechanism for decreased auditory input. These findings suggest that SSD leads to plasticity within higher-order control-related networks as well as cross-modal plasticity. However, studies investigating the impact of partial hearing deprivation on cognition-related regions and networks are still limited in SSD.

Functional connectivity (FC) is another useful tool for investigating network reorganization, and it is defined as the temporal dependence of neuronal activity patterns of anatomically separate brain regions ( Biswal et al., 1995 ;Cole and Schneider, 2007 ;Friston et al., 1993 ). Compared with task-based studies that examine task-driven brain activity, resting-state imaging approaches provide the unique advantage of examining FC without theorydriven tasks. Most of the previous task studies in SSD employed auditory tasks based on the hypothesis that the auditory system was probably reorganized due to the loss of auditory input from one ear, which limited the investigation of other networks. However, resting-state fMRI studies, especially those employing datadriven voxel-wise analysis of the whole brain, are not restricted by these assumptions. Several resting-state fMRI (rs-fMRI) studies in SSD have observed FC alterations in visual and cognition-related networks, including default mode networks (DMNs) and dorsal attention networks (DANs) ( Liu et al., 2015 ;Schmithorst et al., 2014 ;Xu et al., 2016 ;Zhang et al., 2015 ;Zhang et al., 2018 ). These results further demonstrate that there are modulations of visual functions and higher-order cognitive functions in SSD.

Most of the existing SSD studies via rs-fMRI approaches assume that the FC remains stationary during the entire fMRI scanning process. Emerging studies have revealed that FC is dynamic and associated with rhythmic activities ( Allen et al., 2014 ;Hindriks et al., 2016 ;Pedersen et al., 2018 ). As one of the most commonly used strategies for examining dynamics in rs-fMRI, the sliding windowbased approach quantifies the time-varying behavior of the chosen metric over the duration of the scan ( Hutchison et al., 2013 ). It has been applied to examine multiple types of psychological traits and clinical disorders, such as schizophrenia ( Damaraju et al., 2014 ;Fu et al., 2018 ), depression ( Kaiser et al., 2016 ;Wu et al., 2019 ), and Parkinson's disease ( Fiorenzato et al., 2019 ). Thus, investigating dynamics in patients and healthy controls could reveal underlying behavior-and activity-level plasticity caused by diseases and disorders, thereby enabling an understanding of the substrates from a novel perspective. Nevertheless, the sliding windowbased approach has two drawbacks. First, the hyperparameters of the sliding window model are usually set empirically, which leads to difficulties in explaining the reason for choosing the window size and stride length, etc. Second, a fixed-time sliding window cannot effectively capture long-and short-term collaborations between brain regions, which requires a more flexible dynamic window control method ( Bansal et al., 2019 ). Currently, there are studies that attempt to use the brain state and transition probability to bypass window settings to achieve dynamic FC based on statistics and data-driven methods. For example, Vidaurre et al. (2017) studied the resting brain dynamic functional network and found two nonrandom and hierarchical connection modes (or meta-states) derived from the transition probability matrix via a hidden Markov model (HMM) for healthy subjects. Although these studies have made significant contributions to the field, the research question of how to comprehensively exploit the dynamic connectcome under different temporal terms is still largely unsolved.

To address the aforementioned challenges and issues, in this study, we proposed a randomized window-based dynamic functional connectivity (rdFC) method to extract dynamic characteristics for SSD under different terms and augment the dataset by taking advantage of window randomness. To evaluate the performance of our method, after feature selection with a t -test, we utilized a linear support vector machine (SVM) model to learn the discrimination principles between the rdFC features and labels, including left single-sided deafness (LSSD), right single-sided deafness (RSSD) and healthy controls (HCs). Then, to validate the practicability of the proposed method, we analyzed the classification performance with the linear SVM classifier using rdFCs and compared it with that of traditional static functional connectivity (sFC) and dynamic functional connectivity (dFC). We hypothesized that the rdFC method would be able to differentiate these three groups of subjects more accurately than sFC and dFC. We also examined the coefficients outputted by the model, which described the importance of each feature and presented a connectivity pattern analysis for identifying patients with SSD and HCs. We hypothesized that data-driven rdFC for rs-fMRI provides more information on the brain plasticity of patients with SSD and that widespread reorganization of the networks related to auditory, visual and cognitive control systems would probably be observed.

div.head: Participants
div.p: Forty-three adult SSD patients were recruited from the clinic in the Department of Otorhinolaryngology of Peking Union Medical College Hospital, including 23 participants suffering from left single-sided deafness (LSSD, 15 males; 44.1 ± 11.7 years old; one left-handed) and 20 participants with right single-sided deafness (RSSD, 9 males; 39.0 ± 9.2 years old; one left-handed). In addition, twenty-five adult volunteers with normal hearing were recruited as healthy controls (HC, 13 males; 42.2 ± 14.8 years old; one left-handed). This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Peking Union Medical College Hospital. All participants signed an informed consent form before study enrollment and MRI scanning.

All SSD participants had persistent severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss with average pure tone audiometry (PTA) thresholds > 70 dB HL on the deaf side for more than two years and normal hearing on the other side. Among all participants, 3 LSSD patients and 2 RSSD patients failed to provide their exact onset age of deafness and were probably prelingual, and the rest of the SSD patients had a post-lingual onset. Additionally, the definition of normal hearing was considered to be an air conduction PTA threshold of ≤ 25 dB HL from 0.5 to 2 kHz. The average PTA threshold was also defined as an average air conduction threshold from 0.5 to 4 kHz. All SSD patients reported that they had no history of hearing aid use. In addition, all three groups of participants had normal speech comprehension and normal or correctedto-normal vision in their daily lives.

To prevent disturbances caused by factors not related to SSD, before and during the experiment, all participants were confirmed to have no (i) history of substance, drug or alcohol dependence (assessed by a self-reported statement); (ii) history of psychiatric or neurological disorders or cognitive decline (measured by the Mini-Mental State Examination, scale score < 27); (iii) observable brain abnormalities examined by MRI; (iv) metal devices such as electronic implants; or (v) excessive head movements during the scan (the criterion is that the mean framewise displacement value ex-ceeds 0.5 mm or the maximum displacement caused by head motion is larger than 1 mm). As a result, four SSD patients (including two LSSD patients) and one HC participant were excluded. The demographic and clinical information of the participants is shown in Table 1 .

All three groups of participants were matched with respect to age, sex, handedness and years of education. There were no significant differences in the PTA threshold for the normal-hearing ears among the three groups ( F = 2.44, P = 0.09) or for the deaf ears between the LSSD and RSSD groups ( t = -0.36, P = 0.72). Among the three groups, all participants were confirmed to have normal speech comprehension. Furthermore, there were no significant differences in the duration of deafness ( t = 0.44, P = 0.66) or onset age of deafness ( t = 0.62, P = 0.54) between the LSSD and RSSD groups.

div.head: MR image acquisition and preprocessing
div.p: The functional images were collected on a 3T Philips Achieva MRI scanner (Philips Healthcare, Best, The Netherlands) with a 32channel head coil. Head motion was controlled by tight but comfortable foam padding.

Resting-state BOLD images were collected using a gradient echo-planar imaging sequence with the following parameters: 37 axial slices; repetition time (TR) = 2300 ms; echo time (TE) = 35 ms; flip angle (FA) = 90 °; slice thickness = 2.5 mm; gap = 1.0 mm; matrix = 96 × 96; field of view (FOV) = 240 × 240 mm 2 . During the scan, the participants were instructed to lie still in the scanner, with their eyes closed, remaining relaxed but awake without deliberately thinking of specific things. The resting-state scan lasted 6 min and 8 s (184 volumes).

High-resolution T1-weighted structural images in the coronal view were acquired with a slice thickness of 1 mm without gaps. The specific sequence parameters were TR = 57.46 ms, TE = 2.98 ms, FOV = 240 × 240 mm 2 , and matrix = 240 × 240 × 160.

The functional images were preprocessed by using the GRETNA ( https://www.nitrc.org/projects/gretna ) ( Wang et al., 2015 ) and SPM12 toolkits ( https://www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.uk/spm ). In the first stage of image processing, the first 10 acquired fMRI images of each participant were discarded to ensure magnetization equilibrium. The preprocessing of the rs-fMRI data included slice timing correction with the first slice and head motion correction. The unified segmentation algorithm was utilized as the affine transformation for registration. To perform the group analysis, the first scan of the remaining fMRI time series was coregistered to each participant's T1-weighted image and then normalized to the Montreal Neurological Institute (MNI) template space. Nuisance signal regression (including 24-parameter head motion profiles, global signal, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) signal, and WM signal) was performed to remove the noise components. The data were spatially smoothed with a 4 mm full-width at half-maximum Gaussian kernel. A linear temporal detrend and a bandpass filter of 0.01-0.10 Hz were also utilized.

div.head: Network construction and data augmentation with randomized window-based dynamic FC
div.p: As mentioned in the introduction section, conventional dynamic FC requires a sliding window with a predefined stride length and window size to slide on the signals of each brain region, and the relevant eigenvalues between each window are calculated ( Hindriks et al., 2016 ;Hutchison et al., 2013 ). By analyzing the variation in these eigenvalues, the synergy and local patterns of brain regions are better utilized than by using traditional static FC ( Fig. 1 A). However, this sliding window approach has the aforementioned two drawbacks, namely, the absence of connective patterns under different temporal terms and the absence of interpretable parameter settings for each specific clinical label, which require a more flexible dynamic window control method.

In the present study, we utilized a randomized window mechanism to solve the aforementioned problems and further exploited the characteristics of this random-based approach to augment existing brain network datasets from a limited number of existing fMRI images. As presented in Fig. 1 A, by giving a defined number of windows n and a range of window sizes l max and l min , our pro-posed method randomly generates different windows to capture partial signals from each brain region. For the i th window, we first obtain a specific window size l i through uniform sampling from l max to l min . Based on l i , we then locate the window by randomly selecting a possible position p i in the signal sequence of nodes R . Thus, we finally derive the window sequence ws : ws = { w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w n } where w n = { R p n , . . . , R p n + l n } . We utilize a 246-region-based brain atlas, namely, the Brainnetome Atlas ( Fan et al., 2016 ), to establish brain parcellation to define nodes in the brain network. Un-der the effect of randomness, the proposed variable window can capture the respective signals of different brain regions under different terms of the time span so that it can better capture similar collaborative activities of the brain regions in the long-and short-term patterns. In addition, when applying the proposed procedure repeatedly on an rs-fMRI image, different sequences of the window are generated, thereby forming different connectivity matrices. In this study, we believe that this feature enables multiple corresponding connectivity matrices to be generated for a patient by using only one rs-fMRI scanning process. In this approach, we define the above sampling and resampling process as a data augmentation approach because it generates multiple usable features from one scan, which generates only one feature with a traditional approach, by introducing random factors. Considering the contradiction between the relatively high fMRI acquisition cost and the relatively large sample size needed for statistical and machinelearning methods, the proposed data augmentation method provides a novel perspective for solutions.

Fig. 1 A compares the proposed FC method with existing sliding window approaches. The sFC approach calculates the correlations among signals of different nodes, while the conventional dFC approach selects a fixed time window and then calculates a graph-based attribute or eigenvalue of the graph defined in this time window. In addition, cerebral metastasis identification-based approaches generate dynamic FCs through the transitions of brain states. For example, Vidaurre et al. utilized a hidden Markov model to identify brain states and then computed the transition probability between each pair of states, thereby deriving the dynamic FC matrix on these probabilities ( Vidaurre et al., 2017 ). Compared with these methods, our proposed rdFC approach focuses more on capturing the graphic eigenvalue under different spatiotemporal terms to generate dynamic brain FC.

It is worth mentioning that our proposed method of data augmentation is based on the hypothesis that the connectivity matrices generated in different iterations for a single participant are mutually more similar than the matrices for other participants. This hypothesis has been validated by Finn et al. and Vidaurre et al. with different designs and implementations of dynamic FC ( Finn et al., 2015 ;Vidaurre et al., 2017 ). Therefore, to validate this hypothesis with the proposed rdFC, we performed an exploratory analysis by calculating the Pearson's correlation coefficient ( r ) between each connectivity matrix from either the same or different individual rs-fMRI images, as shown in the Results section. Additionally, to make the results between the participants more rigorously comparable, we used the same random window sequence for each participant.

div.head: Using nodal efficiency correlation to construct a brain network based on amplified functional connectivity
div.p: After deriving each window sequence ws , we aggregate them into a single matrix for feature representation, namely, the nodal efficiency-based correlation matrix (NECM). Unlike commonly used connectivity matrices, the NECM expresses the synchronous correlation of activities between brain regions as measured by node efficiency. Specifically, for one participant in a sample iteration s , the nodal efficiency of node x in window w is calculated by Achard and Bullmore (2007 ):
div.formula: E nodal ( x ) = 1 N − 1 y = x ;x,y ∈ G s,w 1 L xy
div.p: where L xy is the shortest path length between x and another region y in the connectivity matrix G s,w , which is defined according to the following equation:
div.formula: L xy = a xy ∈ g x → y a xy
div.p: where a xy denotes the positive weight (i.e., positive correlation in this study) between two nodes on the shortest path, defined by g x → y , for the given G s,w . E nodal (x ) represents the average shortest path length between x and all the other nodes in network G s,w . It should also be noted that before further processing, the order of the windows is determined according to their position indexes, the aim of which is to preserve the time-related dynamic pattern. Furthermore, although we used a random method to capture the window on the fMRI signals, the window sequence for each participant was the same. Specifically, we randomly generated a set of window sequences and used the same window collection process for each participant according to the generated sequence to ensure the repeatability and interpretability of the experiment. Additionally, the reason for using nodal efficiency is that it is a graphic property that quantifies the degree of ease of information exchange over a graph. This measurement provides information on the communication efficiency of the graph overall, with higher values indicating more efficient information transfer throughout the whole brain.

Let E s,w (x ) denote the vector of the nodal efficiencies of node x ( { E s, 1 ( x ) , E s, 2 ( x ) , . . . , E s, 3 ( x ) , . . . } ) , and Pearson's coefficient r calculated between E s,w (x ) and E s,w (y ) is defined in terms of the elements of the NECM. This approach aggregates the dynamic connectivity feature in multiple windows into a single matrix, which is used to describe the correlation of nodal efficiency changes between each pair of brain regions ( Fig. 1 B).

div.head: Using the linear SVM to learn the relationship between rdFC and single-sided deafness
div.p: Although the previous sections reduce the feature spaces to a two-dimensional matrix and establish data augmentation on the original dataset, an extra feature selection step is still required to prevent the overfitting problems caused by the large number of elements in the NECM before using the machine learning algorithms. In this study, we applied a t -test to exclude linearly uncorrelated features. In addition, the results of using LASSO/mRMR as a feature selection method are provided in the Supporting Information (Table S1). For simplicity, we name the elements in the NECM (i.e., features) 'nodal efficiency similarity' to describe the relationship between two brain regions (or brain nodes). For each nodal efficiency similarity in the NECM, we sort the value of similarity into one of three groups according to the clinical label (i.e., LSSD, RSSD and HC) to which the corresponding NECM belongs. A nodal efficiency similarity was kept only when it was statistically significant ( p -value < 0.05) between any two clinical groups.

The nodal efficiency similarities selected by this filtering method have a potential linear relationship with the clinical labels of the participants. Therefore, we used a linear kernel-based SVM model to assess the relationship between the nodal efficiency similarities and the SSD label ( Fig. 1 C).

Assume we have a training set T = { ( x 1 , y 1 ) , ( x 2 , y 2 ) , . . . , ( x N , y N ) } , where x i ∈ R n is the filtered nodal efficiency similar- ity and y i ∈ { −1 , +1 } represents the clinical label ( i = 1 , 2 , . . . , N).
By setting the penalty coefficient C > 0 , we construct a convex quadratic programming problem:
div.formula: min α 1 2 N i =1 N j=1 α i α j y i y j x i • x j − N i =1 α i s.t. N i =1 α i y i = 0
div.p: where 0 ≤ α i ≤ C, i = 1 , 2 , . . . , N. Then, we obtain the optimal solution α * = ( α * 1 , α * 2 , . . . , α * N ) T . Thus, we calculate
div.formula: ω * = N i =1 α * i y i x i
div.p: We select a component α * j from α * that satisfies the condition 0
div.formula: < α * j < C to calculate b * = y j − N i =1 α * i y i x i • x j
div.p: When an unseen sample x appears, we can predict the clinical label of the sample from ω * and b * :
div.formula: f x = sign ( ω * • x + b * )
div.p: Where sign () is the signum function.

To ensure the generalization of the model and avoid overfitting problems, we split the dataset into training and test sets. There is no intersection between the data in these two sets and no intersection between the participants included in the two sets. In this experiment, we exploited leave-one-out cross-validation (LOOCV) to assess the performance of the classification models.

It is worth mentioning that here, we considered only the linear relationship between the nodal efficiency similarities in the NECM and SSD. To evaluate the performance of the linear SVM and our proposed method, we performed a comparison of the classification accuracy of the test set by using sFC, sliding window-based dFC and our proposed rdFC. In addition, we used the precision, recall and F1 score to assess the performance in classifying, SSD patients, HCs, LSSD patients and RSSD patients:
div.formula: P recision = T P T P + F P Recall = T P T P + F N
div.p: where T P , F P , and F N denote the true-positive, false-positive and false-negative predictions, respectively. The F1 score is calculated by combining the precision and recall:
div.formula: F 1 = 2 • P recision • Recall P recision + Recall
div.p: Additionally, to determine the effect of the number of sampling times, we analyzed the variation in the precision, recall and F1 score by using different sampling times.

We also conducted a permutation test to investigate whether the obtained metrics were significantly better than would be expected by chance. In the experiment, we permuted the clinal labels across all participants 10 0 0 times, and we reapplied the above cross-validation procedure each time. This eventually resulted in a distribution of F1 score values reflecting the null hypothesis that the model did not exceed chance. The number of times that the permuted value was greater than the true value was then divided by 10 0 0 to provide an estimated p -value for the classification performance analysis ( Feng et al., 2018 ). Furthermore, to determine whether the use of different FCs significantly affects the prediction results, we used the corrected chi-square test to evaluate the classification contingency table.

div.head: Discriminative connectivity analysis
div.p: We establish the unbiased interpretability of the classification model by exploiting the values in ω * . We regard each value in ω * as a coefficient that corresponds to the nodal efficiency similarity in x . After demonstrating the effectiveness of the classification model in identifying LSSD, RSSD and HC, we examine these nodal efficiency similarity coefficients as connectivity contributions to identify SSD and perform the analyses below.

Regarding the brain network, we sum the absolute coefficients of the nodal efficiency similarities that belong to the same network as defined by Yeo et al. (2011 ). All the summed coefficients are further processed by the normalized Fisher Z -score. Since each NECM feature involves two brain regions, our network-based analysis includes 11 cross-network and 7 intra-network connectivity patterns (Table S2).

We also utilize a brain map to show the contributions at the brain region level. We take the regions and areas from the brain atlas and map them to a three-dimensional brain model by using the normalized Fisher Z -score of the summed nodal efficiency similarity coefficients. This approach reveals the key regions that are connected by multiple discriminative features. In this study, we utilized Brain Net Viewer as the visualization tool ( Xia et al., 2013 ).

div.head: Data replication study
div.p: To validate our methods in the main study, a data replication experiment was performed by using an rs-fMRI dataset of 41 external participants recruited by the University of California, San Francisco. There were 16 LSSD, 11 RSSD and 14 HC participants enrolled. Detailed information has been described elsewhere ( Henderson-Sabes et al., 2019 ) and in the Supporting Information (Table S3). The imaging data were acquired by using a 3-Tesla MRI scanner (Discovery MR750, GE Medical system, Waukesha, WI). The participants were asked to insert foam earplugs with a 32-dB noise reduction rating into both ears during data acquisition. T1-weighted fast spoiled gradient echo brain volume images were collected with the following parameters: axial slices = 120; field of view = 256 × 256 mm 2 , repetition time = 7.2 ms, echo time = 2.78 ms, in-plane voxel dimensions = 0.5 × 0.5 mm 2 , and slice thickness = 1.5 mm. The resting-state BOLD images were collected using a resting-state echo-planar imaging (EPI) sequence with the following parameters: 1.88 × 1.88 mm 2 , slice thickness = 3.0 mm, repetition time = 20 0 0 ms, echo time = 28 ms, and 100 repetitions. The subsequent processing steps were consistent with those described in the main study. In this data replication study, we compare the classification performance measured by the F1, precision and recall, and permutation test among sFC, dFC and the proposed rdFC with the same linear SVM model, thereby assessing the generalization of the proposed dynamic FC.

div.head: Data augmentation via randomized window-based dynamic functional connectivity
div.p: The data augmentation was conducted using a two-step approach, which consists of in-window and NECM calculations. In this study, we enhanced the original rdFC-based dataset 1 to 10 times to observe how it affected the classification performance. In Fig. 2 , we show the Pearson's correlation coefficient between each pair of data samples with 5 augmentations (a-e). To facilitate comprehension, we show the correlation between the first 20 samples separately for each of 4 participants (Sub 1-Sub 4) on the right side of the original matrix. This result strongly suggested confirmation of the proposed hypothesis that the connectivity matrices generated from one participant in different iterations are more similar to each other than to matrices from other participants.

div.head: Performance of predictive classification with the linear SVM model
div.p: After data augmentation, t -test-based feature selection was performed, and the linear SVM was applied to compare the classification performance on the test set with the three approaches of generating FCs, as described in the Methods section. Based on the feature selection, the linear SVM model was applied to learn the data samples from the training set and predict the SSD status of unseen samples from the test set. The accuracy of the threeway classification experiment via the proposed approach was 0.84, while the accuracies of the dFC and sFC approaches were 0.81 and 0.69, respectively. Furthermore, compared with the static and sliding window-based dynamic approaches, our proposed randomized window-based dynamic FC achieved the best performance in identifying patients with LSSD vs. HCs, patients with RSSD vs. HCs and patients with LSSD vs. those with RSSD, with an improvement in the F1 score, precision and recall ( Table 2 ). It should be noted that the stride length of the dFC window was 1, and the size of the window in dFC was determined based on the performance when we tested different window sizes (window size = 25, 35, 45, 55, 65, and 75). The number of windows is determined by the entire length of the time course and the stride length of the window. In addition, we also kept the same number of total windows of rdFC as the number of dFC windows to ensure consistent experimental conditions. The results show that our proposed method can improve the F1 score from 0.88, 0.83 and 0.71 to 0.91, 0.88 and 0.91, respectively, in the three tasks, which proves that the classification model can obtain sufficient knowledge to identify SSD from the proposed rdFC. Furthermore, the results of the data replication study showed that the proposed rdFC also yielded the best classification performance compared with sFC and dFC when we replaced the current dataset with another dataset; detailed information is included in the Supporting Information (Tables S3 and S4). By performing the corrected chi-square test on the prediction result between each baseline FC and rdFC, we observed statistical significance when using sFC ( p -value = 0.02) and HMM ( p -value = 0.04), while no statistical significance was observed when using dFC ( pvalue = 0.79).

In addition, we investigated the performance of the classification model with different iterations of data augmentation to examine how this affects the classification performance. As previously described, for each sampling time, we generated a list of random windows and applied this list to all participants' fMRI signals, thereby generating an NECM for each participant. In another sampling process, we repeated the same process with different random window sequences, thereby generating a different NECM for each participant. As shown in Fig. 3 , when the number of samples is less than 5, the performance of the classification model is significantly improved with increasing samples. However, when the number of samples reaches 5, the F1 value of the classification model plateaus, and the classification performance eventually reaches a tendency toward a stable status.

div.head: Discriminative connectivity analysis
div.p: Based on the effectiveness of our proposed method, we performed a contribution analysis of the features (i.e., nodal efficiency similarities) using the linear SVM model as described in the Methods section. The contribution analyses were performed by calculating the normalized Fisher Z -score of the cumulative NECM feature coefficients provided by the classification model.

We first investigated the brain network-level connectivity patterns by categorizing the NECM features into Yeo's 7 network ( Fig. 4 ). In all three tasks, the nodal efficiency similarities linked to the frontoparietal network and the somatomotor network were identified as making the greatest contribution to the classification model. In addition, the FCs involved in the DAN and DMN were observed to make a major contribution to identifying clinical groups. Specifically, the nodal efficiency similarities of the dorsal attention network, the limbic network and the dorsal attention-somatomotor network played significant roles in the classification model, indicating more significant alterations in the nodal efficiency similarities related to these networks. From the perspective of the difference in connectivity patterns among different classification tasks, the features based on the frontoparietal-limbic network and the intra-dorsal attention network showed a major contribution to distinguishing patients with RSSD vs. HCs and patients with LSSD vs. those with RSSD but not those with LSSD vs. HCs, while intrafrontoparietal network nodal efficiency similarities were regarded as effective for the classification model only in the LSSD vs. RSSD task.

In the coefficient analysis at the brain region level ( Fig. 5 ), we observed brain regions that had larger connectivity coefficients ( > 0.25). The left superior frontal gyrus (SFG), right superior parietal lobule (SPL) and left orbital gyrus (OrG) were the major contributors to identifying patients with LSSD, those with RSSD and HCs in all three tasks. Regarding the difference in connectivity patterns between different classification tasks, it was observed that the contribution of the right superior temporal gyrus (STG), left middle temporal gyrus (MTG), left amygdala (Amyg), and right in-ferior frontal gyrus (IFG) had a more obvious contribution to classifying RSSD and HC, while the right SFG was more helpful in classifying LSSD and HC. Additionally, it was observed that the cingulate gyrus (CG) and insular gyrus (INS) were helpful for identifying LSSD vs RSSD and LSSD vs HC. However, such limbic and insular areas were not observed in the task of classifying RSSD patients and HCs (Table S5).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In the current study, we investigated dynamic FC alterations in SSD using a data-driven randomized window-based approach. Several major observations should be noted: (1) By augmenting the dataset using the rdFC method, the features of SSD can be differentiated from those of HCs with better accuracy than by using either sFC or dFC. (2) Using the present novel method, FCs related to the frontoparietal, somatomotor and limbic networks and to the DAN and DMN were observed to play a major role in differentiating SSD from HC and exhibited significant alterations in SSD, with the FCs between the frontoparietal and somatomotor networks playing the most important role. ( 3) At the region level, FCs related to the SFG, SPL, STG, Amyg and OrG made major contributions to the differentiation tasks, indicating significant FC alterations to these regions in SSD.

Small dataset problems are a widely existing challenge faced by medical imaging studies. As a solution to this problem, data augmentation has received extensive attention for a long time ( Cubuk et al., 2019 ). In the present study, we enhanced the data using a randomized window-based dynamic FC calculation. As shown in Fig. 2 , our hypothesis that data augmentations of the same participant are more similar to each other than to samples from other participants has been confirmed to be consistent with existing dynamic FC studies ( Finn et al., 2015 ;Vidaurre et al., 2017 ). Afterward, we compared the classification performance of rdFC with that of traditional sFC and dFC. According to the results of our multiple evaluation parameters, the data augmentation method we proposed can distinguish among patients with LSSD, those with RSSD and HCs more effectively, indicating that the proposed rdFC and data augmentation are helpful for extracting the NECM features of SSD. Furthermore, the consistent results shown by the data replication study confirmed that our proposed rdFC could provide better features for distinguishing SSD patients and HCs than traditional sFC and dFC could. Regarding application, in contrast to previous FC studies of SSD, the present study yielded acceptable results using a sample size of approximately 20 partic- ipants for each group. Our results revealed the potential of using this rdFC method in studies of other rare diseases.

It should be noted that the proposed rdFC method does not replace or deny the contribution of current neurological studies with large samples. The purpose of this method is to demonstrate how to make full use of dynamic FC information under different temporal terms as much as possible, thereby achieving more accurate classification as well as better interpretations of neurological changes in disorders such as SSD. The number of NECMs was multiplied according to the specific sampling time. Using this approach, we can generate multiple data records from one participant, thereby making the classification model learn more information from existing features and improving the classification accuracy. Thus, we suppose the proposed method is a data augmentation approach. Since data augmentation is a computing resourcesensitive operation, the more samples that are applied, the longer the computational time. Therefore, we also studied how to select the applicable augmentation factor that can bring the greatest performance improvement with the minimum computational time. The results of comparisons using different augmentation factors showed that the accuracy of the classification model initially increased with increasing samples but plateaued after the number of samples reached 5. This phenomenon indicates that data augmentation can provide more features for the classification model, but the effect of this supplement gradually decreases with increasing samples. Thus, five may be a reasonable number of samples for the present method.

Furthermore, because the neural plasticity reported in previous SSD studies is located in multiple regions of the brain, using unbiased assumptions is more helpful in analyzing the connections in the whole brain ( Liu et al., 2015 ;Qiao et al., 2019 ;Wang et al., 2019 ). Thus, data-driven statistical learning methods such as machine learning are able to facilitate self-learning on a separate training set from the perspective of identifying the relationship between the label and the data, and the effectiveness of the learning can be verified by comparing the predicted labels of the samples in the unseen test set with the actual labels ( Dubois and Adolphs, 2016 ;Yarkoni and Westfall, 2017 ). Based on an accurate and robust prediction model, outputting the model's interpretable feature importance provides an unbiased analysis of the regions and connections ( Shen et al., 2017 ). However, due to the high cost of fMRI acquisition and strict subject selection procedures, the number of participants collected in clinical trials is often limited. Datasets of this size have caused overfitting problems to some degree when using machine learning models. Thus, we employed the aforementioned data augmentation method on the existing samples and satisfied the requirement of using the data-driven method under the constraint of a limited number of subjects.

Using the present data-driven rdFC method, the FCs between the somatomotor and frontoparietal networks were revealed to make the most important contribution to differentiating patients with LSSD from HCs and those with RSSD from HCs, indicating the most significant alterations that occurred. Furthermore, networks related to higher-order cognitive functions, including the DMN, DAN and limbic networks, were also revealed to play an important role in the differentiating task. In addition, according to the region-level analysis, multiple regions related to cognitive function, including the SFG, SPL, OrG, IFG and CG, were observed to contribute the most to differentiating SSD patients from HCs. Numerous previous studies investigated rs-fMRI alterations in SSD using both theory-and data-driven methods. Several studies observed altered FC between the auditory cortex and the frontoparietal lobe using the seeded method ( Liu et al., 2015 ;Qiao et al., 2019 ). Zhang et al. (2015) also observed significant FC alterations in the DMN in SSD. In addition to FCs, Wang et al. (2014) observed regional homogeneity alterations in SSD in the calcarine cortices, anterior insular cortex and parahippocampal cortex and altered FC between the anterior insular cortex and several key regions of the DMN. Yang et al. (2014) observed significantly altered amplitudes of low-frequency fluctuations in the precuneus, inferior parietal lobe (IPL), IFG, insula, inferior temporal gyrus (ITG) and middle temporal gyrus (MTG). Our study provides new insights into the effect of SSD on brain function under different temporal terms. It has been proven that SSD requires greater effort to accomplish auditory tasks, including sound localization ( Pavani et al., 2017 ) and speech recognition in noise ( Hornsby, 2013 ;Lewis et al., 2016 ), because there are fewer cues (e.g., an absence of intensity differences, binaural squelch, and interaural time differences) to complete these peripheral auditory system tasks ( Abel and Lam, 2008 ;Ruscetta et al., 2005 ). Additionally, cognition-related regions such as the frontoparietal areas and insula cortex were demonstrated to be more involved in auditory processing tasks when increased listening effort was needed in individuals with hearing loss. Thus, we regard this additional recruitment as a decreased auditory input-triggered compensatory mechanism ( Berding et al., 2015 ;Campbell and Sharma, 2013 ;Erb et al., 2013 ;Peelle et al., 2011 ;Rudner and Rönnberg, 2008 ). Our findings suggest that alterations in the amount and pattern of cognitive resource recruitment are the major plasticity in SSD. Correspondingly, the results from previous structural connectivity studies are consistent with our findings to some extent. Shang et al. ( 2018) observed extensive frac-tional anisotropy alterations over the frontal and parietal lobes. Li et al. (2018) reported significant enhancement in the frontoparietal subnetwork connectivity strength, and higher-order auditory function (such as speech recognition in noise and sound localization) correlated significantly with the structural connectivity strength of the cognitive regions. These findings suggest that the reorganization of cognition-related networks is the most important structural plasticity pattern in SSD. However, studies of the underlying morphology and molecular-level mechanisms in SSD should be performed to further clarify the underlying mechanism.

Since many previous studies on SSD have indicated obvious alterations of the interhemispheric symmetry and synchronization of the auditory system, significant alterations in connectivity were expected for the auditory cortex ( Khosla et al., 2003 ;Langers et al., 2005 ;Ponton et al., 2001 ). Furthermore, previous FC studies using the primary auditory cortex as the seed revealed significant FC alterations in SSD ( Liu et al., 2015 ). However, it is notable that the auditory cortex is not among the regions that played the most important role in differentiating SSD patients and HCs according to the region-level analysis. This is probably because the present study, which used a data-driven approach, calculated the relative weights of the FCs rather than the absolute values, which is different from region of interest (ROI)-based studies focusing on the auditory cortex. Our results suggest that the FC alterations in the networks related to cognitive control were most important, which does not mean that there is no significant reorganization in the auditory cortex. A previous data-driven study of structural connectivity networks obtained similar results, whereby increased connectivity strengths in the frontoparietal subnetwork and decreased connectivity strengths in the visual network, but not the auditory network, were observed (Li et al., 2018). In addition, it was observed that the higher-order auditory functions most affected in SSD were associated with the structural connectivity strength of the cognitive regions rather than the auditory cortex.

We also investigated the difference between LSSD and RSSD. The two SSD groups could be differentiated very well, with an accuracy of 91%, by our rdFC method, indicating that there is a significant FC difference between them. According to the networklevel results, the FCs between the somatomotor and frontoparietal networks show the most significant difference, and alterations also occur mainly in networks related to higher-order cognitive functions, including the DAN, DMN and limbic and frontoparietal networks. According to the region-level results, SFG, SPL, OrG and MTG showed the most significant differences. Furthermore, although the pattern and areas of plasticity were generally similar according to the results of the classification tasks for distinguishing patients with LSSD vs HCs and those with RSSD vs HCs, it seems that more obvious plasticity occurs in the right hemisphere among patients with LSSD and in the left hemisphere among those with RSSD. The results of previous studies have suggested that the impact of RSSD is different from that of LSSD and that RSSD seems to produce more significant changes, which is probably due to hearing asymmetry ( Li et al., 2019 ;Qiao et al., 2019 ;Schmithorst et al., 2014 ). Furthermore, it has been revealed in previous auditory stimulation-based studies that there is a rebalancing between ipsilateral and contra-auditory processing in SSD patients ( Ponton et al., 2001 ;Scheffler et al., 1998 ). Our results suggest that differences in plasticity occur not only in the auditory pathway but also in regions and networks related to higher-order cognitive functions. These findings suggest that the amount and pattern of cognitive resource recruitment may be different between different sides of SSD.

However, this study has some limitations that should be noted. First, although the proposed random window sampling method affords the possibility of data augmentation, the computational time cost of this operation is still relatively high. For example, in the experiment, if we chose to collect n random windows for each subject, rdFC would require n times the number of calculations as traditional static FC as well as a calculation of nodal efficiency. Therefore, the optimization of the calculation is important for applying the proposed method. The prediction results are inevitably related to the characteristics of the dataset. In this paper, a relatively simple feature selection method is selected in the experiment. However, this choice does not mean that other feature selection methods are not suitable for this task. In addition, Table S1 shows that the LASSO-based approach has certain advantages, and the calculation of mutual information shows that the feature selection method used in this experiment significantly improves the average mutual information between the selected features and the labels compared with the average mutual information of all features. These results may depend on the distribution of the current dataset; therefore, further investigation with a larger clinical dataset is warranted. Second, since the etiology of SSD is diverse, further subdividing SSD (for instance, adult onset vs. congenital) may help to improve the accuracy of the classification model such that more accurate analysis results can be obtained. Third, our study is based on the underlying linear characteristics of the participants as a group, ignoring nonlinear factors and individual differences. We believe that interindividual differences and nonlinear characteristics require further investigation to meet the demands of more personalized clinical services.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In the present study, we proposed a randomized window-based approach to extract dynamic FCs and augment the original dataset. Based on the extracted and augmented dataset, we investigated the FC alterations in SSD using a data-driven method. The rdFC method showed better performance in identifying patients with LSSD, patients with RSSD and HCs with a linear SVM model. Networks and regions related to higher-order cognitive functions showed the most significant FC alterations in SSD. These findings may indicate a compensatory collaboration of cognitive resources in SSD.

div.head: Declaration of Competing Interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

figure.figDesc: Abbreviations: LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HC = healthy control; PTA = pure tone audiometry; SD = standard deviation.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. The pipeline of the current study. (A) FC construction (for each sample) by the proposed method (rdFC) compared with counterparts using traditional static FC (sFC) and fixed sliding window-based dynamic FC (dFC). (B) Calculation of the nodal efficiency-based correlation matrix. (C) The process of our experiment. We first validate that the linear SVM model can accurately classify the LSSD, RSSD and HC participants by using the proposed dynamic FC and then analyze the connectivity pattern by referring to the coefficient of each feature in the learning model. Abbreviations: FC = functional connectivity; LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HCs = healthy controls; SVM = Support Vector Machine.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. The similarity matrix between each pair of data samples after data augmentation. The right section of the figure is a magnified display of the correlation between the twenty samples (1-a-4-e) of four participants (Sub 1-Sub 4).

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. Variation in the performance of the classification model with different sample numbers. Abbreviations: LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HCs = healthy controls.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. Yeo's 7 network-based feature (nodal efficiency similarity) coefficient analysis. Abbreviations: LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HCs = healthy controls.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. Coefficient map obtained by mapping NECM feature coefficients into Brainnetome Atlas-based brain regions. Abbreviations: LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HCs = healthy controls; NECM = nodal efficiency-based correlation matrix.

figure.head: Table 1
figure.figDesc: Demographic and clinical information of the participants.

figure.head: Table 2
figure.figDesc: Classification performance of sFC, dFC, HMM and rdFC using the linear SVM model. The p -values were estimated by the permutation test.
figure.note: Abbreviations: SVM = support vector machine; LSSD = left single-sided deafness; RSSD = right single-sided deafness; HCs = healthy controls; HMM = hidden Markov model; sFC = static functional connectivity; dFC = sliding window-based dynamic functional connectivity; rdFC = randomized windowbased dynamic functional connectivity.

div.head: Acknowledgment
div.p: We thank Steven W. Cheung, Srikantan S. Nagarajan, Leighton B. Hinkley, Corby Dale and Chang Cai at the University of California, San Francisco, for their contributions to this work. We would also like to thank all participants, including the SSD patients and HC volunteers. This research was partly supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant Nos. 62071049 , 61801026 ) and the National Key Research and Development Program of China (Grant No. 2020YFC20 0520 0 ).

div.p: Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi: 10.1016/j.media.2021.102163 .
